text:
Running the MSI installer with parameters, e.g:

> msiexec /i "$R0" /quiet /passive /qn /norestart SERVERADMIN=test@test.com AGREETOLICENSE="Yes" ALLUSERS=null APPLICATIONUSERS="OnlyCurrentUser" INSTALLDIR="$Apache_Home" SETUPTYPE="Typical" SERVICENAME=apache2.2

results in an error message in the installer, that the server admin field is not set in httpd.conf and that the service cannot be started. 
Upon closer inspection, when the installer is finished, this field value is blank in httpd.conf.
I would expect the field to be set to "test@test.com" in this case.

Side note: Is there a way to tell apache installer not to start the service?
creator: alix.warnke@assaabloy.com

text: Since the service is started after the installation it will result in popups with error messages (service will fail to start) so the workaround, to replace the value in the config file after the installer has run, is not good enough. That is the reason why I changed importance from normal to major
creator: alix.warnke@assaabloy.com

text:
Confirmed.  Only affects quiet installation.  Simpler test case:
msiexec /i httpd-2.2.22-win32-x86-no_ssl.msi /quiet SERVERADMIN=dummy@example.com

SERVERADMIN is admin@localhost in httpd.conf after installation.

Disregard my last comment; I was looking at the wrong configuration file.

SERVERDOMAIN and SERVERNAME must also be set if you set SERVERADMIN.  This is apparent from when you install httpd interactively.  I verified that SERVERADMIN is properly set when SERVERDOMAIN and SERVERNAME are also set:
> msiexec /i httpd-2.2.22-win32-x86-no_ssl.msi /quiet SERVERADMIN=foo@example.com SERVERDOMAIN=example.com SERVERNAME=bar
creator: dw549@hotmail.com
